title: How do we study living brains? - John Borghi and Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary challenge in studying the human brain?

options.text: Its protective layers and billions of interconnected cells

options.label: A
options.text: It is non-invasive and relatively inexpensive

options.label: B
options.text: It can pinpoint differences in brain activity to within a few millimeters

options.label: C
options.text: It is thousands of times slower than fMRI

options.label: A
options.text: It can pinpoint differences in brain activity to within a few millimeters

options.label: C
options.text: It is thousands of times slower than EEG

multiple-choice.question: What technique measures radioactive elements introduced into the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: It can pinpoint differences in brain activity to within a few millimeters

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary limitation of brain imaging techniques?

options.label: C
options.text: They are limited by how much we still don't know

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for brain diseases

options.label: D
options.text: To connect what happens in the brain with our behavior

multiple-choice.question: What is the future of brain research?

options.label: A
options.text: It will focus on developing new treatments for brain diseases

options.label: B
options.text: It will focus on improving brain function

options.label: C
options.text: It will focus on understanding how the brain works

options.label: D
options.text: It will focus on connecting what happens in the brain with our behavior and understanding what's happening in each region of the brain, how they work together, and whether the activity is because of their involvement in memory or another process occurring simultaneously.
